about.heading: Regional Scrum Gathering® Cape Town 2019
about.description: Regional Scrum Gathering® Cape Town 2019 is an annual conference where software professionals and Agile enthusiasts meet to uncover better ways of working and developing software
about.feedbackDescription: Please answer a collection of questions about the conference which will be used to improve your experience next year. This should take around 1-2 minutes of your time. Your feedback will remain anonymous.

questions.name: satisfaction
questions.text: How satisfied were you with the conference?

questions.name: objective
questions.text: In your opinion, did the conference meet its objectives?

questions.name: structure
questions.text: How well was the conference structured?

questions.name: discussion
questions.text: Was there enough time for discussion?

questions.name: topics
questions.text: Which topics would you like to see covered at future conferences?

sessions.description: Please visit the Welcome Desk on the conference level to register.
sessions.name: Registration & Networking

speakers.about:
Natalie Warnert is founder, president and executive director of Women in Agile Inc., a nonprofit organization which enables, empowers, and expands the distribution of new and diverse ideas in the agile and technology communities worldwide. She is a frequent speaker on business and agile topics including product strategy, user experience, and emotional intelligence. Her strategy focuses on actions you can implement tomorrow for immediate impact that track toward longer-term vision and outcomes. Natalie also brings unparalleled humor to all her engagements (or so she thinks).

Natalie is passionate about guiding companies as they design, execute, and support their approach to cultural change as an independent consultant at her company, Natalie Warnert LLC. Her vast thought leadership experience is recognized by her numerous keynotes, podcasts, and publications including being a SAFe framework contributor and creator of the UX Runway. Natalie has earned various degrees and certifications over the past decade including her Master of Arts in Organizational Leadership, SAFe Program Consultant and Framework Contributor, Certified Scrum Professional, and Six Sigma Yellow Belt. For more of Natalie’s work please visit www.nataliewarnert.com
speakers.name: Natalie Warnert

sessions.description:
The Lean Startup and Product Kata mindset of small, targeted experiments is a great way for products to determine how to expand meaningfully and sustainably while examining data and experience collected along the way. These tools can also be expanded to organizations that provide non traditional products such as services, information, and other types of messaging to target their audiences' needs in the right ways. One example of this is the Women in Agile movement, which started like most products do, with curiosity about a problem. Now it has grown to a non-profit organization with local groups across the world and many conference pairings under its belt all in a timeframe of a few years. Natalie will discuss the Lean Startup and Product Kata themes using Women in Agile as a case study. Learn how these product frameworks were used to expand a movement, that does not provide a physical "product", to get to where it is today, a global non profit with over 4000 members, and how you can take our lessons learned to nurture your curiosity, organizations, and non traditional "product" ideas in a successful and sustainable way.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Understand how to implement the Product Kata to design experiments and analyze data/metric changes in your target problems to solve
  • Learn to apply the Lean Startup and Product Kata concepts to services and organizations/movements (versus traditional physical or software products)
  • Articulate the Women in Agile story as a non traditional movement built and cultivated through curiosity, experimentation, and decentralization
sessions.name: Nurturing Diversity in Technology Through Lean Startup & Product Kata

speakers.about: Justin hails from the Mother City. He is in pursuit of living in a world filled with innovative businesses, happy teams, and a dancing squirrel. As an Agile guy, he often inspects & adapts, and recites the Agile Manifesto in the shower. After leaving South Africa in 2016 he has been coaching, mentoring and learning at Spotify in Stockholm and New York City
speakers.name: Justin Kotze

sessions.description:
It's not easy balancing the workload that comes with: driving improvement in business impact, delivery performance, and team health in organizations as an SM or Coach. It is often difficult to articulate to folks what you are working on, how you are doing it and why. Do you need help with this?LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • How to make use of this engagement model in your own context as an Agile Coach or ScrumMaster
  • Building capacity in teams to be less reliant on you
  • How to balance many different requirements on you as an Agile Coach or ScrumMaster
  • Using coaching contracts in your organization
  • Balancing pushing coaching onto the org and having the capacity for ad hoc opportunities and asks
  • Exactly how our model looks and you will get to use it and take it with you
sessions.name: The Agile Coaching Engagement Model You Always Needed

sessions.description:
Getting new teams to work together is hard. We believe that the key to high-performance teams is creating an intentional high-performance culture. Join us as we explore the Team Canvas covering the elements that make teamwork work.

Get ready to sprint-off your team in 3... 2... 1…

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Learn facilitation techniques that will instantly help you in your role as a facilitator or Scrum Master.
  • Stop unproductive team conflict before it starts, by discussing things that matter to the team BEFORE they start working together.
  • Get everyone onto the same page. Fast!
  • Understand the essential elements to make teamwork work.
  • How to use the Team Canvas to create an intentional team culture that respects and embraces diversity.
sessions.name: 3... 2... 1... We Have Sprint-Off

speakers.about: I am a product owner who loves traveling, experiencing different cultures and trying out new cuisines. I love meeting new people with whom we can swap stories and experiences.
speakers.name: Wambui Muiru

sessions.description:
This is a story of my journey as a product owner and my personal experience in the agile space. I've had to un-learn a lot of the methods I had perfected for the last 6 years. However, instead of feeling like I had wasted those many years, I felt re-born.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Evaluating if the methods we are currently using are as effective as we think they are
  • How to use failure as a learning tool
  • How to encourage dropping of obsolete practices rooted in our work culture
sessions.name: From a Project Manager to a Product Owner: The Devolution of Power

speakers.about: Malene Jacobsen is one of the few people that have never done a Waterfall project. She was taught Agile/Scrum from the first day of her education in Advanced Computer Scientist and since then it became a natural way of thinking both in work and private life. Malene fully lives up to the saying: you don’t do agile, you become agile! Malene started her professional career as a Web Developer but quickly decided to be more client faced and therefore became an IT Consultant with responsibility for different projects as a Product Owner. In her professional career, she has fulfilled all scrum roles, Developer, Product Owner and Scrum Master and she realized that her passion is to teach other people in the understanding of the Scrum framework. In 2015 Malene moved from Denmark to South Africa (Cape Town) where she now shares her deep passion and joy for agile as an Agile coach and trainer at Agile of Course.
speakers.name: Malene Bendixen

sessions.description:
Can agile really drive you insane? Being part of a constantly changing world is not easy. As Coaches, Scrum Masters, etc. it is expected of us to go in front and be servant leaders - but we are also only human and the reality is not always that simple. How do you look after yourself in this world?

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Describe scenarios that can create stress.
  • Explain how the agile mindset can impact people negatively.
  • Combine and apply 5 tools learned at the talk to destress your life.
sessions.name: Is Agile Driving You Insane?

speakers.about: Cara is the CEO and Agile Coach at Project codeX, an agile-first software training programme that equips aspiring coders with high quality skills and experience, while bridging the digital divide. She started her software career in 2001, initially in project-management environments, with an increasing focus on agile practices from 2008. Over that time she has held positions in operational, product team, coach and leadership roles - including her current role as CEO of Project codeX, which she balances with agile coaching for software teams. Agility is at the heart of both roles - helping teams adopt agile practices that reduce risk and increase workplace happiness, and bringing agility to education, training developers with a collaborative, continuous learning approach from the start. She has a boundless love of learning, and cares deeply about sharing knowledge to build stronger communities and foster greater diversity in the software world.
speakers.name: Cara Turner

sessions.description:
Software teams live with uncertainty: it's hard to plan for most of our work. Not just because things change - there are also different types of Unknowns, with different ways to approach each. More than a plan, we really need a way to identify our uncertainty, and choose a route to take from there.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Understanding of the 5 Orders of Ignorance
  • Being able to tell Known Unknowns, Unknown Knowns & Unknown Unknowns better than Donald Rumsfeld
  • Understanding that:
    • Being uncertain is actually a valuable state to be in, as long as we can recognise what we feel uncertain about
    • It is possible to recognise what it is we donâ€™t know
    • It is possible to start learning *from* a question
    • There are different strategies for different kinds of unknowns
sessions.name: Deliberate Discovery Workshop: A Learning Approach to Uncertainty

speakers.about: Alistair Sloley is an Agile consultant, specializing in Agile training, Agile coaching, and software development best practices. Alistair is a fifteen-year veteran of Microsoft where he acted as a Program Manager, Software Test Engineer, and Software Design Engineer in Test. At Microsoft, he shipped in over ten products, worked with Microsoft Research on multiple high-profile projects, and helped lead his organization into enterprise-level implementation of Scrum. As an Agile consultant for Steve McConnell at Construx Software, he led Agile transformation efforts at a variety of clients, spanning industries and incorporating a diverse range of Agile practices.
speakers.name: Alex Sloley

sessions.description:
How can an Agile Coach figure out when an Agile Transformation is going wrong? Are there signs that they might see and heed? Of course, there are! We will discuss transformation provider types, frameworks, keywords, and other anti-patterns that might be signs that THE END IS NIGH.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Attendees will learn that Agile Transformations have some consistent warning sign themes.
  • Attendees will learn to identify common warning signs.
  • Attendees will learn what happens after warning signs are escalated
sessions.name: The End is Nigh! Transformation Apocalypse!

speakers.about: As a keen Agilest, I enjoy growing teams and the individuals within. Whilst I don’t subscribe to or propose rigid frameworks and methodologies I do believe creating a safe space for growth which encourages experimentation and learning is the key to cultivating excellence. From a technology perspective, I’m primarily experienced in the .Net space, while somehow always looking after teams with mobile projects. I enjoy research and development and creating proof of concepts of new ideas and technologies. I also have experience in more low level development for more academic projects where performance was key. Over the years my experience has ranged from mobile development to creating secure communication tools; academic research projects to enterprise development more recently; working with students to helping my teams achieve their best. All of this and "ten-ish" years in the industry made me who I am, a developer with interests growing towards coaching and mentoring teams.
speakers.name: Hans Roos

sessions.description:
As developers, our tools are technical, our problems are technical but on a daily basis we are required to be creative when implementing solutions. I want to challenge conventional wisdom by discussing the process of developing software as a creative one instead of a technical one.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • I would like you to walk away understanding, how thinking of development as a creative process will help you better collaborate with your “technical team” leading to better team success.
sessions.name: But is it Art?

speakers.about: Divashen briefly spent some time exploring the world of radio-astronomy and astrophysics whilst completing his BSc in Applied Mathematics and Physics. He has always had a deep curiosity and passion for space science, technology and the social impact of space exploration. Upon graduating he made the move to software development and joined Jumo as a Software Engineer. He is also one of the 100 remaining international astronaut candidates for the Mars One project, which aims to establish a human settlement on Mars in 2031. Divashen enjoys being involved in outreach in South Africa using his involvement in the Mars One project as a vehicle to drive interest and expose the youth to STEM.
speakers.name: Divashen Govender

speakers.about: Adam started out in the world of geography, focusing on GIS. His experiences have led him to the world software and product management. Adam finds himself hung up on the ever changing world of product management, and strives to one day get on top of it all. He is passionate about keeping the link between software and what’s happening in the real world, as well as mastering the craft of product management. Adam’s first gig as a PM was in university working on a GIS for Health Care, he has gone on to work on products that promote the visibility and effective management of mining rights throughout Africa and infrastructure asset management. Adam is now a product owner at JUMO. When he is not spending time delivering products to drive financial inclusion in developing countries, you might find him on the nearest mountain.
speakers.name: Adam Ricketts

speakers.about: Kirsten began her career in counseling and psychology and then moved into software. She has found facilitating and coaching Agile teams deeply rewarding as the role allows her to bring a lot of the things she cares deeply about together. She is currently working at Eyeo (AdBlock Plus) as a Team Coach. Previously she worked at Jumo as a Scrum Master and Facilitator and 22seven as an Agile Facilitator
speakers.name: Kirsten Clacey

sessions.description:
Creating an environment that enables team members to learn from each others roles and responsibilities makes us stronger and more impactful inside and outside our team. We’d like to share 6 principles we believe have been central to enabling this and some supporting practices and behaviours.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Understand the value of creating and fostering cross-functional learning in a team
  • Identify and recognise elements of one’s environment which contribute to safe learning in a team
  • Discover some practices that support learning in a team
sessions.name: Training as a (T)eam

speakers.about: Christopher Human was born and raised in Cape Town and has been a PHP developer for nearly 10 years. He has worked on projects big and small for a host of clients over the years. He has also served as team lead on a few development teams, all of whom lacked proper Scrum guidance. Having been through the good, the bad and the ugly of Scrum, he has taken a casual interest in Agile in recent years, and enjoys learning from other people's Agile experiences and seeing how everyone is interpreting Agile processes and making it work for them.
speakers.name: Christopher Human

sessions.description:
When it comes to code, the way developers manage it can mean the difference between a successful or a blocked release. Having experienced these issues personally, in this talk I'll explain some of the issues I've experienced and show how my team and I manage our code today mitigating these problems.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • A basic understanding of version control and code repositories
  • A strategy that developers can follow in order to plan and organise their code in an Agile manner
  • An understanding of how Product Owners can aid their developers in maintaining this strategy
sessions.name: Achieving Agility with Code Repositories

speakers.about: I am a recovering Project Manager. In a career spanning 40 years, I have been on my own agility journey for 20 years so far. I try to help leaders to understand and embrace modern ways of leading and managing in the quest of growing resilience within their organisations. In doing so I use an eclectic toolbox that includes Kanban, Scrum, Cynefin, OrgScan, Flight Levels, ORSC, the Thinking Environment, NVC and more within a scaffold called ORGANIC agility. Day to day I teach these frameworks and tools, and I coach individual leaders and teams of leaders. I aspire to travel less, and to write more.
speakers.name: Peter Hundermark

sessions.description: Leaders everywhere are talking about how to survive and thrive in our world. ORGANIC agility offers a complexity-based approach to help every leader guide their organisation on its unique journey to becoming and remaining resilient. Join this short workshop to taste ORGANIC agility in action.
sessions.name: ORGANIC Agility: A Complexity- based Approach to Growing Resilient Organisations

speakers.about: Lorraine Steyn is a self-described geek who loves software and solving problems. With over 30 years experience in running a software development company, she has a lot to share. Lorraine has presented Internationally at a number of conferences in both the Agile and Domain Driven Design (DDD) fields, as well as being a frequent speaker and supporter at our local Meetups and conferences.
speakers.name: Lorraine Steyn

speakers.about: Ayesha is a Scrum Master with a great empathy for people. She focuses on building trust and openness, and is especially passionate about growing diversity and inclusiveness in IT.
speakers.name: Ayesha Bagus-Casker

sessions.description:
Event Storming is a relatively new technique that helps business and technical teams to gather requirements in a very interactive manner. It’s ideal for feature discovery, and encourages everyone to participate. Once you’ve tried it, you will always want to start a new feature or product this way!

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Participants will learn the theory behind Event Storming;
  • We’ll practice the technique in groups at a strategic as well as tactical level;
  • You’ll see how much functionality emerges in the discovery phase, and hopefully will leave the workshop with a strong understanding of this new and very useful Requirements Gathering method.
sessions.name: Gathering Requirements Through Event Storming

speakers.about: Bevan has been an IT professional since 2009 and is currently an Agile Coach & Trainer at Think Agile. He has previously worked as a Software Engineer, Scrum Master and Manager for a team of developers in Taipei. His passion is coaching, enabling and leading people to do their best work, focussing on personal, career and organizational growth.
speakers.name: Bevan Williams

sessions.description:
Do you hate how things work around you? Are you curious about how this negative emotion can be used to drive you to be a more impactful leader? Learn how to use this oft-avoided topic to make positive changes in your own life, and how those can influence others to make changes in theirs.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Use your hatred of things around you to create a positive vision for the future
  • Learn how to identify the feeling of hate and use it to your advantage
  • Feel ready to achieve that next big step in your life with self-compassion
sessions.name: Using Hate to Achieve Your Goals and Influence Others

speakers.about: I was in sales for much of my early career. I enjoyed the Sales process and putting people in touch with products that they would enjoy. I then moved more into the IT related environment where I got to stretch my Logical side, yet still get to relate to customers and provide them with great service quality. As a Test Analyst I have had the opportunity to put Testing best practices into place as well as be part of an excellent team which successfully Built up a website for our Company from the ground up. Being exposed to the Agile Methodology is a new arrow in my quiver and it has been very enlightening. You think you know the best way of doing things...Until you take the blinkers off and realise you don't know everything. It took me a long time to find a Career path which truly inspired me and aligned with my Beliefs. With the Scrum Master role I have found this! Now a full time Scrum Master and its been a amazing journey so far, You learn more, Grow more and build up those around you as you seek to meet your team and customers needs! I don't think it is always realised what a privilege it is to be a Scrum master, you get to shape and grow those around you, making their lives better and help them realise their full potential. What a calling it is!
speakers.name: Nivan Moodley

sessions.description:
Lets Chat.... Me .. you...your PO...Your Team Afraid? uncertain? Come to this session and gain insight on how to cultivate these important working relationships

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • How to get my team to open up and trust me as Scrum master
  • Gain insight into how to get my PO to work with me
  • Learn Effective ways to communicate with Snr management
sessions.name: The Wall Must Fall!

speakers.about: Stuart Mann is a reformed waterfall guy who is now a passionate Agile Coach. He is a father (two girls), husband (one wife) and a trainee feminist. In his spare time, Stuart is a compulsive marathon runner. He has run over 200 marathons and ultras. He writes a monthly column for South Africa's largest running publication (Modern Athlete) and contributes athletics articles to Sport24. Stuart's lifetime ambition is to secure a beer sponsor.
speakers.name: Stuart Mann

sessions.description:
Understand how your brain works and how this applies to relative size estimation. I will strain your brain with an "absolute" estimation exercise before inducing a blissful nirvana-like state by flipping the example around to a "relative" estimate.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Why we suck at absolute estimates
  • Why we win with relative estimates
  • How you can apply this to story and feature sizing
sessions.name: Everything's Relative - The Brain Science Behind Why We Are So Much Better at Relative Rather Than Absolute Estimation
Registration for those that never made it on Day 1

speakers.about: Cara is the CEO and Agile Coach at Project codeX, an agile-first software training programme that equips aspiring coders with high quality skills and experience, while bridging the digital divide. She started her software career in 2001, initially in project-management environments, with an increasing focus on agile practices from 2008. Over that time she has held positions in operational, product team, coach and leadership roles - including her current role as CEO of Project codeX, which she balances with agile coaching for software teams. Agility is at the heart of both roles - helping teams adopt agile practices that reduce risk and increase workplace happiness, and bringing agility to education, training developers with a collaborative, continuous learning approach from the start. She has a boundless love of learning, and cares deeply about sharing knowledge to build stronger communities and foster greater diversity in the software world.
speakers.name: Cara Turner

sessions.description:
Agilists have built a wealth of knowledge and practices for working with uncertainty. Yet all too often we find ourselves following a plan rather than responding to change. This session make sense of the tools we have to truly harness the discovery process, charting our journey through the unknown.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • This talk is aimed at agilists who need to navigate traditional control methods in otherwise agile environments.
  • It provides insight into the deep thinking behind agility, in a light and accessible format.
  • Frameworks for thinking about Discovery
  • Using sense-making to map our work, rather than upfront planning
  • What it means to defer commitment responsibly
  • The role agile practices play in discovery
sessions.name: Dancing with Uncertainty: Navigating Unknowns from Inception to Maintenance

speakers.about: Passionate about people and delivery through Lean|Agile approaches, with a focus on creating awesome collaborative working environments. As a partner leading the agility@IQbusiness offering at IQ Business since 2012, I have built an amazing team of Agile consultants (largest in South Africa) that share a common purpose of continuous learning and improvement. Together with the team, we have trained over 6000 people on Agile and been involved in some of the largest Agile transformations in financial services industry. Worked in the Software Development industry since 1999 and as passionate as I am about people, I am equally passionate about delivery of great software products Live by the boy scout principle of "Leave the camp site in a better way than what you found it.”
speakers.name: Biase De Gregorio

sessions.description:
How do you go about building a high-performing Agile consulting team, with the purpose of laying the foundation for better working environments for the next generation & beyond? Join me in my story of some of the challenges, lessons learnt & tips for anyone considering embarking on this journey.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Understand some of the challenges in building an agile consulting team in South Africa
  • Apply some of the tips in the lessons learnt in creating high-performing teams
  • Outline leadership practices and principles in a consulting environment where oftentimes agile values and principles conflict with shareholder needs
sessions.name: A Pinch of Design, Some Luck and a Lot of Passion and Hard Work - My Journey in Building an Awesome Agile Consulting Team

speakers.about: Chris is a software architect with 20+ years experience, committed to evolutionary and constant learning, often tinkering with new tools, technologies, techniques and architectures. He is passionate about quality software and great architecture, while forging the growth of this generation of software developers. Chris enjoys sharing his learnings, often accompanied by good beer. Chris can be found either overseeing the architecture at Kaleidocode, mentoring on the Kaleidocode apprenticeship program, or working hands on with his team.
speakers.name: Chris Tite

sessions.description:
We use time boxed cycles, shorter feedback cycles and small defined outcomes to run projects . Why not use this approach to mentor and grow staff? I have been doing this for 5 years. The outcome; higher job satisfaction and less burn-out among employees. Let me show you how.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • The motivation for an agile mentoring approach
  • The agile mentoring approach and the agile mentoring life cycle
  • Personas adopted in agile mentoring
  • The people patterns adopted in agile mentoring, including anti-patterns
  • The tools used to manage the process, including the career framework
sessions.name: Mentoring and Growing Stronger Teams Using Agile Techniques

speakers.about: Annu is an Electronics and Communication engineer and a certified Pragmatic Marketing (PMC) professional. Annu has 20 years experience in the technology sector; she started her career as a software developer. She later transitioned to technology product management and worked for a number of companies ranging from innovative startups to established corporates. In 2016, she decided to follow her passion and founded [NedRock](http://www.nedrock.com/), a product management training and consulting company. She is passionate about helping corporates, accelerators and entrepreneurs creating products that are valuable and usable and feasible. She trains and consults on Lean Startup, Customer Development and Agile methodologies. She also advises tech startups on growth strategies and lean analytics. In 2018, she was elected as one of the fifty most inspiring South African women in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics. She is also a speaker and has spoken about product management at Google Women’s Techmakers program and Chief Technology Office (CTO) conference.
speakers.name: Annu Augustine

sessions.description:
Product owners should be obsessed with delivering value to customers.They should interact with customers by conducting interviews. This enables them to make sound product decisions, write valuable stories & be the voice of the user. Join this workshop to learn how to conduct effective interviews.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Formulate the right customer interview questions
  • Define learning goals for customer interviews
  • Develop active listening skills
  • Synthesize interviews using a visual format
sessions.name: Discovering Value Through Customer Interviews

speakers.about: Justin Doyle is Head of Enterprise Agile at Discovery, a leading financial institution in South Africa. In over fifteen years of software development experience he has seen first-hand how technology is changing the world at an exponential rate. In this era of constant change, he firmly believes that we need to create responsive, agile organisations that harness technology and new ways of work to adapt to change and invade the future at speed and scale. This is what drives his passion for Agile. As an Agile Coach he has worked to embed the values, principles and practices needed to create responsive organisations that are effectively equipped to serve their evolutionary purpose and solve real customer needs and problems.
speakers.name: Justin Doyle

speakers.about: Kim Dowdeswell is a registered industrial/organisational psychologist, expert talent advisor and research analyst with over 15 years of experience in the assessment and advisory field. I strive to help people live meaningful whole lives through enabling them to understand who they are and empowering them to find their best fit in the working world. Over the years I have gained wide-ranging experience consulting to organisations in South Africa and Africa, empowering executives to make better-informed people decisions using credible data-driven insights and quantifying the return on talent initiatives through evidence-based business outcomes. I am particularly interested in the use of psychological and other similar assessment in the South African context, upholding best practice in assessment in a global economy, and building inclusive and fair working environments.
speakers.name: Kim Dowdeswell

sessions.description:
Is Servant Leadership awesome, or is it merely a reflection of rebranded western value-based leadership models, perpetuating outdated perspectives? This workshop aims to engage delegates with thought-provoking discussion as to their perceptions of ideal leadership in the agile workplace.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Understand the benefits of servant leadership in the workplace
  • Create a shared understanding of servant leadership in the South African context
  • Understand international perspectives on what constitutes servant leadership
  • Identify a success profile for servant leaders in South Africa
  • Identify barriers to practicing effective servant leadership in South Africa
sessions.name: Servant Leadership for Mzanzi?!

speakers.about: Justin hails from the Mother City. He is in pursuit of living in a world filled with innovative businesses, happy teams, and a dancing squirrel. As an Agile guy, he often inspects & adapts, and recites the Agile Manifesto in the shower. After leaving South Africa in 2016 he has been coaching, mentoring and learning at Spotify in Stockholm and New York City
speakers.name: Justin Kotze

sessions.description:
Is your company adopting OKRs? Perhaps you already have a lot of experience on OKRs and you want some inspiration by hearing on how it's been iterated on and implemented in a Business Unit at Spotify. Or perhaps you'd just like to know more about OKRs.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • What are OKRs
  • Common pitfalls to look out for when implementing OKRs
  • A bit of the Spotify spirit in action modifying a process to make it work
sessions.name: Carefully Navigating the World of Objectives and Key Results

speakers.about: I currently work at Jumo as an Agile Lead and as a volunteer committee member for Scrum User Group South Africa (SUGSA). I think the most amazing thing about me is that I became a scrum master by "accident" but now I can't imagine doing anything else. I really love finding new ways to encourage collaboration and transparency and connecting with other communities. My favourite things are building lego and playing games.
speakers.name: Jay-Allen Morris

speakers.about: Nelson currently works at Luno as a software engineering manager. He has a passion for developing people while enabling the development of software. Nelson is excited by challenging problems and finding new ways to solve them. He has been exploring the Agile space by attending courses and meetups.
speakers.name: Nelson Nogueira

sessions.description:
What if we have the mindset of ‘it depends’ instead of ‘I know’, how might that change the outcome? You will learn how we fostered a space where we mindfully bent the rules of Scrum to create a custom process that enabled a production support team (BAU) to move to a world of feature work.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Be able to think deeply about their current process and critically evaluate which parts of their process are done out of habit vs intention.
  • Challenge their own beliefs and understand that using scrum by the book may not always be the answer and blindly implementing may cause more harm than good,
  • Leave with one action they could experiment with and take back to their teams
  • Understand that if you’re in a position of influence, your approach to team process can have a huge impact.
sessions.name: Slaying the Dragon: An Agile Adventure

speakers.about: Steve is a respected and experienced Agile Trainer, Coaching Mentor, and Open Space Technology Guide. He takes a people-first, facilitative, strategic approach to helping people work together so they can make an impact with grace and speed. Steve holds space for agility by trusting people and enabling them to give voice to the system. At the same time, he offers coaching and mentorship in the pragmatic practices and tools that help people develop lean and agile mindsets and skill- sets. Steve’s coaching strengths are product development, facilitative leadership, and the learning journey of fluent agile teams. He’s a practiced leader on enabling communication that makes a difference with Open Space Technology, and Agile Chartering. Knowing that today's team rooms are located virtually "in the sky", he's become adept at facilitating outcome-based collaboration that is thriving and alive whether the group is meeting face-to-face or interconnected across the world. Steve lives in Zurich, Switzerland and travels the world. He enjoys the friendly Swiss summers and the sunny beaches of Cape Town, South Africa. He hopes to do a 3-month volunteer turn with SANCCOB (South African Foundation for the Conservation Of Coastal Birds) rescuing Northern Rock Hoppers and helping the endangered South African Black Foot penguin survive the impact of human activities on their habitat.
speakers.name: Steve Holyer

sessions.description:
How can you shift and maybe declutter the culture of your organisation by "holding space"? This session asks: What do the principles and law of an Open Space event reveal about joy and agile practice across your organisation? You're invited to refine your stance for sparking joy … and shift culture across organisational systems.

  • Would you like to clear clutter from the complex system where you practice agility?
  • How do you cultivate an Agile mindset for yourself and others?
  • Does your the way you show up in your organisation, your stance, spark joy in yourself and others?
  • Open Space Events like Agile Coach Camp, a regional Agile Unconference, or an internal open space company event can spark joy, and also help you cut through the clutter surrounding you in the systems where you practice.
  • Now, let’s explore ways Open Space Technology can be game-changing for agile organisations.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Describe the principles of Open Space and explain how they relate to agility (and support it) in an organisation
  • Use the "law of mobility" to enhance your coaching and leadership stance and create change in your organisation.
  • Explain "holding space" and relate it to systems thinking.
  • Evaluate new ways to lead by "invitation", and start leading by invitation
  • Implement practical ways to encourage autonomous self organisation and name related agile practices both well-known and emerging
  • Create or refine your stance for open space leadership when you return home
sessions.name: The Life Changing Magic of Holding Space:  A Stance for Decluttering Your Organisational Space

speakers.about: Testing is not just a career to me, it is a massive part of who I am. I have been blessed to come across people who have inspired me and taught me and I believe I have been that person to others over the years. The learning never stops though, and I continue to practice the craft and apply learnings from other disciplines back into software testing. I am at my happiest when I see a team able to do their best testing work and add valuable information into the system. One way I like to do this is to be part of the team. Mentoring and coaching the team from an external viewpoint is also something I am comfortable with. I realise that much of the work we do is heavily influenced by the greater system we are in. I have many years experience of making these things visible and coming up with practical ideas to maximize the value derived from the testing efforts. Building the craft and community of testing in South Africa is also a passion of mine.
speakers.name: Louise Perold

sessions.description:
Are your customers happy with your product? Do you have a large on-call team to support production? Do you have a long lead time for any change due to the massive testing effort required? Does your team panic about making changes? Do you have a war room? How can quality emerge in your context? As I have experienced different contexts and been responsible for testing within them, I have grown more and more aware of factors that influence our ability to embrace quality as part of the team culture. In this workshop, I will introduce and use task analysis to:

  • understand what might be getting in the way of a quality culture
  • uncover potential levers within our teams that could be shifted / changed
  • identify experiments to run and what we should observe to help us optimise for quality

    • LEARNING OUTCOMES

    • What quality is and what is important for quality to emerge;
    • What factors (context drivers) might be influencing quality in your context;
    • Feedback loops that can be included;
    • Frames or factors that can be adjusted to allow quality to emerge through:
      • Observations
      • Reflections
      • Diagrams
      • Discussions
sessions.name: What is Quality and How Does it Emerge Within an Agile Organisation?

speakers.about: Kirsten began her career in counseling and psychology and then moved into software. She has found facilitating and coaching Agile teams deeply rewarding as the role allows her to bring a lot of the things she cares deeply about together. She is currently working at Eyeo (AdBlock Plus) as a Team Coach. Previously she worked at Jumo as an Agile Lead and 22seven as an Agile Facilitator.
speakers.name: Kirsten Clacey

speakers.about: Bee worked as a developer for three years, before changing roles to explore the world of Agile. She currently works with a fantastic team of Agilists at Jumo who inspire her on a daily basis. She Scrum Masters two fully remote teams, and facilitates meetings in the organisation.
speakers.name: Bee Sharwood

sessions.description:
What does a retrospective of only C-suite members look like? How does running a retrospective at the end of a 1 year project add value to the organisation? Most Facilitators/Scrum Masters feel comfortable in the team retrospective space. We know our humans, we know our context and this familiarity lends itself to feeling relatively comfortable and safe (most of the time). However, some retrospectives feel quite different. We want to zoom in on what we call High Stakes retrospectives, looking at what makes a retrospective feel “high stakes” and suggesting a model for facilitators to navigate these spaces.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Knowledge of a basic framework that will increase the impact of retrospectives outside of Scrum teams
  • Comprehension of some of the factors which complicate organisational level retrospectives
sessions.name: Facilitating High Stakes Retrospectives

speakers.about: Professional caffeine consumer. Aside from drinking too much coffee, I also write code, write things that are not code, read books about anything and everything, and occasionally dabble in business. I teach random strangers on the Internet about programming stuff through my Udemy courses. I’ve spoken at DevConf and Agile Africa. I started my career in 2008, and since then, I’ve worked in both very large and very small organisations. Most of my career thus far was spent on building ERP software and banking systems, leading teams, and trying to find ways to do things better. I’m particularly passionate about building great teams and understanding the issues that software is intended to solve. I’m currently employed as an architect at a consultancy in Johannesburg.
speakers.name: Riaan Nel

sessions.description:
We find ourselves in a complex world where technology and business collide. Between business and IT, we don’t speak the same language, we don’t always see things in the same way, and we have different needs – but ultimately, we work towards the same goals. This talk is about effectively navigating your way through our complex world and bridging the gaps that lead to confusion, conflict, and lost productivity. I’ll draw on my experience working at a number of different companies of varying sizes, and talk about some of the common issues that I’ve seen when business and IT teams work together – and how we can solve those issues. Spoiler Alert: Users are not the enemy, even when they give you grief.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

  • Understand the importance of a common understanding across business and technical teams.
  • Understand what motivates other people that you work with.
  • Understand how to communicate effectively.
  • Understand the value of close collaboration.
sessions.name: Beyond Tech:  Confusion, Conflict, and Lost Productivity

speakers.about: Makibinyane Mohapeloa is a professional entrepreneur who has successfully launched multiple businesses. He was named as one of the top 30 young entrepreneurs by the Tshwane Economic Development Agency. Makibinyane is passionate about the growth potential of the African continent as well as the potential role of young people in Africa’s economy. A BCom Marketing Management graduate, Mohapeloa is also a graduate of the Social Entrepreneurship Programme at the Gordon Institute of Business Science (GIBS), as well as the B-BBEE Management programme with the Unisa Graduate School of Business Leadership (SBL) and Wits Enterprise.
speakers.name: Makibinyane Mohapeloa

sessions.description: Allowing employees to run with the planning, design, and implementation of sustainability initiatives is the future of sustainability investing. As Agile teaches us; trusting motivated individuals to get the job done, with the right amount of support, creates the best architecture, requirements and designs. “Millennials are investing in and working for companies that have embraced visible sustainable practices.” Forbes, June 2019 Millennials constitute the largest proportion of society, and are soon to form the majority of the working population. They are putting companies under pressure to invest their time, energy and funds in social, environmental and governance sustainability. This aligns with the requirements of the United Nations Global Compact. Organisations typically drive sustainability top down, with the executive determining, and designing, investment in sustainability measures. However, there is now a golden opportunity for companies and employees to be partners in sustainable transformation. Decentralising the decision-making power enables employees to become co-designers in the sustainability masterplan. The value-based desires of the employees are served simultaneously with their career aspirations. And the buy-in for legitimate implementation increases. If you have been wondering “what role can I play in increasing sustainability; in society, in my work, in the world?” this keynote will inspire you and stimulate ideas you can action.
sessions.name: Closing Keynote: Stop Trying to Do Good, & Start Doing Seriously Good Business

speakers.about: Natalie Warnert is founder, president and executive director of Women in Agile Inc., a nonprofit organization which enables, empowers, and expands the distribution of new and diverse ideas in the agile and technology communities worldwide. She is a frequent speaker on business and agile topics including product strategy, user experience, and emotional intelligence. Her strategy focuses on actions you can implement tomorrow for immediate impact that track toward longer-term vision and outcomes. Natalie also brings unparalleled humor to all her engagements (or so she thinks). Natalie is passionate about guiding companies as they design, execute, and support their approach to cultural change as an independent consultant at her company, Natalie Warnert LLC. Her vast thought leadership experience is recognized by her numerous keynotes, podcasts, and publications including being a SAFe framework contributor and creator of the UX Runway. Natalie has earned various degrees and certifications over the past decade including her Master of Arts in Organizational Leadership, SAFe Program Consultant and Framework Contributor, Certified Scrum Professional, and Six Sigma Yellow Belt. For more of Natalie’s work please visit www.nataliewarnert.com
speakers.name: Natalie Warnert

speakers.about: Justin hails from the Mother City. He is in pursuit of living in a world filled with innovative businesses, happy teams, and a dancing squirrel. As an Agile guy, he often inspects & adapts, and recites the Agile Manifesto in the shower. After leaving South Africa in 2016 he has been coaching, mentoring and learning at Spotify in Stockholm and New York City
speakers.name: Justin Kotze

speakers.about: I am a product owner who loves traveling, experiencing different cultures and trying out new cuisines. I love meeting new people with whom we can swap stories and experiences.
speakers.name: Wambui Muiru

speakers.about: Malene Jacobsen is one of the few people that have never done a Waterfall project. She was taught Agile/Scrum from the first day of her education in Advanced Computer Scientist and since then it became a natural way of thinking both in work and private life. Malene fully lives up to the saying: you don’t do agile, you become agile! Malene started her professional career as a Web Developer but quickly decided to be more client faced and therefore became an IT Consultant with responsibility for different projects as a Product Owner. In her professional career, she has fulfilled all scrum roles, Developer, Product Owner and Scrum Master and she realized that her passion is to teach other people in the understanding of the Scrum framework. In 2015 Malene moved from Denmark to South Africa (Cape Town) where she now shares her deep passion and joy for agile as an Agile coach and trainer at Agile of Course.
speakers.name: Malene Bendixen

speakers.about: Cara is the CEO and Agile Coach at Project codeX, an agile-first software training programme that equips aspiring coders with high quality skills and experience, while bridging the digital divide. She started her software career in 2001, initially in project-management environments, with an increasing focus on agile practices from 2008. Over that time she has held positions in operational, product team, coach and leadership roles - including her current role as CEO of Project codeX, which she balances with agile coaching for software teams. Agility is at the heart of both roles - helping teams adopt agile practices that reduce risk and increase workplace happiness, and bringing agility to education, training developers with a collaborative, continuous learning approach from the start. She has a boundless love of learning, and cares deeply about sharing knowledge to build stronger communities and foster greater diversity in the software world.
speakers.name: Cara Turner

speakers.about: Alistair Sloley is an Agile consultant, specializing in Agile training, Agile coaching, and software development best practices. Alistair is a fifteen-year veteran of Microsoft where he acted as a Program Manager, Software Test Engineer, and Software Design Engineer in Test. At Microsoft, he shipped in over ten products, worked with Microsoft Research on multiple high-profile projects, and helped lead his organization into enterprise-level implementation of Scrum. As an Agile consultant for Steve McConnell at Construx Software, he led Agile transformation efforts at a variety of clients, spanning industries and incorporating a diverse range of Agile practices.
speakers.name: Alex Sloley

speakers.about: As a keen Agilest, I enjoy growing teams and the individuals within. Whilst I don’t subscribe to or propose rigid frameworks and methodologies I do believe creating a safe space for growth which encourages experimentation and learning is the key to cultivating excellence. From a technology perspective, I’m primarily experienced in the .Net space, while somehow always looking after teams with mobile projects. I enjoy research and development and creating proof of concepts of new ideas and technologies. I also have experience in more low level development for more academic projects where performance was key. Over the years my experience has ranged from mobile development to creating secure communication tools; academic research projects to enterprise development more recently; working with students to helping my teams achieve their best. All of this and "ten-ish" years in the industry made me who I am, a developer with interests growing towards coaching and mentoring teams.
speakers.name: Hans Roos

speakers.about: Divashen briefly spent some time exploring the world of radio-astronomy and astrophysics whilst completing his BSc in Applied Mathematics and Physics. He has always had a deep curiosity and passion for space science, technology and the social impact of space exploration. Upon graduating he made the move to software development and joined Jumo as a Software Engineer. He is also one of the 100 remaining international astronaut candidates for the Mars One project, which aims to establish a human settlement on Mars in 2031. Divashen enjoys being involved in outreach in South Africa using his involvement in the Mars One project as a vehicle to drive interest and expose the youth to STEM.
speakers.name: Divashen Govender

speakers.about: Adam started out in the world of geography, focusing on GIS. His experiences have led him to the world software and product management. Adam finds himself hung up on the ever changing world of product management, and strives to one day get on top of it all. He is passionate about keeping the link between software and what’s happening in the real world, as well as mastering the craft of product management. Adam’s first gig as a PM was in university working on a GIS for Health Care, he has gone on to work on products that promote the visibility and effective management of mining rights throughout Africa and infrastructure asset management. Adam is now a product owner at JUMO. When he is not spending time delivering products to drive financial inclusion in developing countries, you might find him on the nearest mountain.
speakers.name: Adam Ricketts

speakers.about: Kirsten began her career in counseling and psychology and then moved into software. She has found facilitating and coaching Agile teams deeply rewarding as the role allows her to bring a lot of the things she cares deeply about together. She is currently working at Eyeo (AdBlock Plus) as a Team Coach. Previously she worked at Jumo as a Scrum Master and Facilitator and 22seven as an Agile Facilitator.
speakers.name: Kirsten Clacey

speakers.about: Christopher Human was born and raised in Cape Town and has been a PHP developer for nearly 10 years. He has worked on projects big and small for a host of clients over the years. He has also served as team lead on a few development teams, all of whom lacked proper Scrum guidance. Having been through the good, the bad and the ugly of Scrum, he has taken a casual interest in Agile in recent years, and enjoys learning from other people's Agile experiences and seeing how everyone is interpreting Agile processes and making it work for them.
speakers.name: Christopher Human

speakers.about: I am a recovering Project Manager. In a career spanning 40 years, I have been on my own agility journey for 20 years so far. I try to help leaders to understand and embrace modern ways of leading and managing in the quest of growing resilience within their organisations. In doing so I use an eclectic toolbox that includes Kanban, Scrum, Cynefin, OrgScan, Flight Levels, ORSC, the Thinking Environment, NVC and more within a scaffold called ORGANIC agility. Day to day I teach these frameworks and tools, and I coach individual leaders and teams of leaders. I aspire to travel less, and to write more.
speakers.name: Peter Hundermark

speakers.about: Lorraine Steyn is a self-described geek who loves software and solving problems. With over 30 years experience in running a software development company, she has a lot to share. Lorraine has presented Internationally at a number of conferences in both the Agile and Domain Driven Design (DDD) fields, as well as being a frequent speaker and supporter at our local Meetups and conferences.
speakers.name: Lorraine Steyn

speakers.about: Ayesha is a Scrum Master with a great empathy for people. She focuses on building trust and openness, and is especially passionate about growing diversity and inclusiveness in IT.
speakers.name: Ayesha Bagus-Casker

speakers.about: Bevan has been an IT professional since 2009 and is currently an Agile Coach & Trainer at Think Agile. He has previously worked as a Software Engineer, Scrum Master and Manager for a team of developers in Taipei. His passion is coaching, enabling and leading people to do their best work, focussing on personal, career and organizational growth.
speakers.name: Bevan Williams

speakers.about: I was in sales for much of my early career. I enjoyed the Sales process and putting people in touch with products that they would enjoy. I then moved more into the IT related environment where I got to stretch my Logical side, yet still get to relate to customers and provide them with great service quality. As a Test Analyst I have had the opportunity to put Testing best practices into place as well as be part of an excellent team which successfully Built up a website for our Company from the ground up. Being exposed to the Agile Methodology is a new arrow in my quiver and it has been very enlightening. You think you know the best way of doing things...Until you take the blinkers off and realise you don't know everything. It took me a long time to find a Career path which truly inspired me and aligned with my Beliefs. With the Scrum Master role I have found this! Now a full time Scrum Master and its been a amazing journey so far, You learn more, Grow more and build up those around you as you seek to meet your team and customers needs! I don't think it is always realised what a privilege it is to be a Scrum master, you get to shape and grow those around you, making their lives better and help them realise their full potential. What a calling it is!
speakers.name: Nivan Moodley

speakers.about: Stuart Mann is a reformed waterfall guy who is now a passionate Agile Coach. He is a father (two girls), husband (one wife) and a trainee feminist. In his spare time, Stuart is a compulsive marathon runner. He has run over 200 marathons and ultras. He writes a monthly column for South Africa's largest running publication (Modern Athlete) and contributes athletics articles to Sport24. Stuart's lifetime ambition is to secure a beer sponsor.
speakers.name: Stuart Mann

speakers.about: Passionate about people and delivery through Lean|Agile approaches, with a focus on creating awesome collaborative working environments. As a partner leading the agility@IQbusiness offering at IQ Business since 2012, I have built an amazing team of Agile consultants (largest in South Africa) that share a common purpose of continuous learning and improvement. Together with the team, we have trained over 6000 people on Agile and been involved in some of the largest Agile transformations in financial services industry. Worked in the Software Development industry since 1999 and as passionate as I am about people, I am equally passionate about delivery of great software products Live by the boy scout principle of "Leave the camp site in a better way than what you found it.”
speakers.name: Biase De Gregorio

speakers.about: Chris is a software architect with 20+ years experience, committed to evolutionary and constant learning, often tinkering with new tools, technologies, techniques and architectures. He is passionate about quality software and great architecture, while forging the growth of this generation of software developers. Chris enjoys sharing his learnings, often accompanied by good beer. Chris can be found either overseeing the architecture at Kaleidocode, mentoring on the Kaleidocode apprenticeship program, or working hands on with his team.
speakers.name: Chris Tite

speakers.about: Annu is an Electronics and Communication engineer and a certified Pragmatic Marketing (PMC) professional. Annu has 20 years experience in the technology sector; she started her career as a software developer. She later transitioned to technology product management and worked for a number of companies ranging from innovative startups to established corporates. In 2016, she decided to follow her passion and founded [NedRock](http://www.nedrock.com/), a product management training and consulting company. She is passionate about helping corporates, accelerators and entrepreneurs creating products that are valuable and usable and feasible. She trains and consults on Lean Startup, Customer Development and Agile methodologies. She also advises tech startups on growth strategies and lean analytics. In 2018, she was elected as one of the fifty most inspiring South African women in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics. She is also a speaker and has spoken about product management at Google Women’s Techmakers program and Chief Technology Office (CTO) conference.
speakers.name: Annu Augustine

speakers.about: Kim Dowdeswell is a registered industrial/organisational psychologist, expert talent advisor and research analyst with over 15 years of experience in the assessment and advisory field. I strive to help people live meaningful whole lives through enabling them to understand who they are and empowering them to find their best fit in the working world. Over the years I have gained wide-ranging experience consulting to organisations in South Africa and Africa, empowering executives to make better-informed people decisions using credible data-driven insights and quantifying the return on talent initiatives through evidence-based business outcomes. I am particularly interested in the use of psychological and other similar assessment in the South African context, upholding best practice in assessment in a global economy, and building inclusive and fair working environments.
speakers.name: Kim Dowdeswell

speakers.about: Justin Doyle is Head of Enterprise Agile at Discovery, a leading financial institution in South Africa. In over fifteen years of software development experience he has seen first-hand how technology is changing the world at an exponential rate. In this era of constant change, he firmly believes that we need to create responsive, agile organisations that harness technology and new ways of work to adapt to change and invade the future at speed and scale. This is what drives his passion for Agile. As an Agile Coach he has worked to embed the values, principles and practices needed to create responsive organisations that are effectively equipped to serve their evolutionary purpose and solve real customer needs and problems.
speakers.name: Justin Doyle

speakers.about: I currently work at Jumo as an Agile Lead and as a volunteer committee member for Scrum User Group South Africa (SUGSA). I think the most amazing thing about me is that I became a scrum master by "accident" but now I can't imagine doing anything else. I really love finding new ways to encourage collaboration and transparency and connecting with other communities. My favourite things are building lego and playing games.
speakers.name: Jay-Allen Morris

speakers.about: Nelson currently works at Luno as a software engineering manager. He has a passion for developing people while enabling the development of software. Nelson is excited by challenging problems and finding new ways to solve them. He has been exploring the Agile space by attending courses and meetups.
speakers.name: Nelson Nogueira

speakers.about: Steve is a respected and experienced Agile Trainer, Coaching Mentor, and Open Space Technology Guide. He takes a people-first, facilitative, strategic approach to helping people work together so they can make an impact with grace and speed. Steve holds space for agility by trusting people and enabling them to give voice to the system. At the same time, he offers coaching and mentorship in the pragmatic practices and tools that help people develop lean and agile mindsets and skill- sets. Steve’s coaching strengths are product development, facilitative leadership, and the learning journey of fluent agile teams. He’s a practiced leader on enabling communication that makes a difference with Open Space Technology, and Agile Chartering. Knowing that today's team rooms are located virtually "in the sky", he's become adept at facilitating outcome-based collaboration that is thriving and alive whether the group is meeting face-to-face or interconnected across the world. Steve lives in Zurich, Switzerland and travels the world. He enjoys the friendly Swiss summers and the sunny beaches of Cape Town, South Africa. He hopes to do a 3-month volunteer turn with SANCCOB (South African Foundation for the Conservation Of Coastal Birds) rescuing Northern Rock Hoppers and helping the endangered South African Black Foot penguin survive the impact of human activities on their habitat.
speakers.name: Steve Holyer

speakers.about: Testing is not just a career to me, it is a massive part of who I am. I have been blessed to come across people who have inspired me and taught me and I believe I have been that person to others over the years. The learning never stops though, and I continue to practice the craft and apply learnings from other disciplines back into software testing. I am at my happiest when I see a team able to do their best testing work and add valuable information into the system. One way I like to do this is to be part of the team. Mentoring and coaching the team from an external viewpoint is also something I am comfortable with. I realise that much of the work we do is heavily influenced by the greater system we are in. I have many years experience of making these things visible and coming up with practical ideas to maximize the value derived from the testing efforts. Building the craft and community of testing in South Africa is also a passion of mine.
speakers.name: Louise Perold

speakers.about: Bee worked as a developer for three years, before changing roles to explore the world of Agile. She currently works with a fantastic team of Agilists at Jumo who inspire her on a daily basis. She Scrum Masters two fully remote teams, and facilitates meetings in the organisation.
speakers.name: Bee Sharwood

speakers.about: Professional caffeine consumer. Aside from drinking too much coffee, I also write code, write things that are not code, read books about anything and everything, and occasionally dabble in business. I teach random strangers on the Internet about programming stuff through my Udemy courses. I’ve spoken at DevConf and Agile Africa. I started my career in 2008, and since then, I’ve worked in both very large and very small organisations. Most of my career thus far was spent on building ERP software and banking systems, leading teams, and trying to find ways to do things better. I’m particularly passionate about building great teams and understanding the issues that software is intended to solve. I’m currently employed as an architect at a consultancy in Johannesburg.
speakers.name: Riaan Nel

speakers.about: Makibinyane Mohapeloa is a professional entrepreneur who has successfully launched multiple businesses. He was named as one of the top 30 young entrepreneurs by the Tshwane Economic Development Agency. Makibinyane is passionate about the growth potential of the African continent as well as the potential role of young people in Africa’s economy. A BCom Marketing Management graduate, Mohapeloa is also a graduate of the Social Entrepreneurship Programme at the Gordon Institute of Business Science (GIBS), as well as the B-BBEE Management programme with the Unisa Graduate School of Business Leadership (SBL) and Wits Enterprise.
speakers.name: Makibinyane Mohapeloa
